ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You learn basic microeconomic theory and calculation techniques. Much of the material in the beginning is relatively basic, but it quickly gets more challenging.
I learned a basic understanding of microeconomics, which included may different types of graphs.
Basic economic knowledge, review of calculus, understanding of economic principles, critical thinking skills
I was introduced to microeconomics and important key concepts for the subject.
economics skills, it's an intro class and I had no background coming in

I learned how to think in an economic mindset and weight costs and benefits. I have a better understanding of how economists, policy makers, and firms make decisions with an eye on short- and long-term implications. I would feel prepared to enter future economic courses at Yale and engage in conversations with people who work in economics-related fields.
I learned the basics of economics including supply and demand, budget constraints, indifference curves, monopolies, pareto efficiency, nash equilibrium, insurance, and time value of money.
None. This course is specifically made around the midterm/finals/psets, and oftentimes you do not feel like you are learning anything substantive.
I learned the basics of microeconomics.
basic knowledge of microeconomics
basic economic knowledge such as supply and demand, monopoly, consumer and producer behavior
I learned to look through the world with an economic lense.
I had my first introduction to economics; I learned a great deal about basic microeconomics.
I learned about the basic economic structures and how they fit into the larger context of our real-world economy.
Basic knowledge of microeconomics
Knowledge of introductory microeconomics
I learned about capitalist economics. I learned why some practical things such as rent control may not work in the U.S. economy
Supply and Demand. Marginal Analysis. Basic Game Theory.
Microeconomics skills and theories
basic understanding of introductory economic concepts
Basic overview of microecon concepts.
the basic introduction to microeconomics, how to graph models
I learned more about the basics of microeconomics and how firms and consumers behave.
I learned the basic foundations for microeconomics and how to apply them to everyday things (e.g., insurance, risk, etc.).
An overview of microeconomics
I developed an introductory-level understanding of fundamental concepts in microeconomics.
basics of perfectly competitive markets, monopolies, and oligopolies and how supply and demand work within these various systems; very standard syllabus
I learned basic principles of microeconomics.
basic insight to microeconomics--exactly as is advertised
I learned foundational economics and its real-world applications.

I learned the basic concepts surrounding a market, supply, and demand. I learned what happens when a market is operating under standard assumptions and situations where those assumptions are broken, such as in the case of monopolies, oligopolies, and forms of market failure.
An introduction to basic microeconomics
Microeconomics
Foundations of economics! Different types of markets and market failures
Ability to use equations and graphs to expand models
basic microeconomic theories, including demand and supply curves, oligopolies, monopolies, etc...
i gained a basic understanding of microeconomic concepts
I learned about how to understand markets on a micro level from the perspective of the consumer, producer, government, social planner, and more
Provided a good introduction into thinking like an economist
General economics topics. Surface level applications of concepts.
Basics of supply and demand in simple markets; Relationship between consumers and producers; Different effects on the market
I learned about economic actions of firms, consumers, and the government. I also learned how to model these economic interactions mathematically and graphically.
I learned the basics of microeconomics (Supply/Demand, Taxes/Subsidies, Externalities, etc).
I learned about the fundamentals of microeconomics and marginal analysis.
An introduction to Economics
I could finally understand some of the stuff my friends talk about all the time
i learned the basics of microeconomics, supply and demand + cournot/bertrand, prisoner's dilemma, etc.

Basic microeconomic conceptssupply and demand, elasticity, indifference curves versus budget constraints, etc.
I noticed myself applying those concepts to the world around me as I learned them.
Analytical and economic thinking, economic evaluation of various mathematical concepts

I developed a basic understanding of how consumers and firms interact and function in the economy, how resources are allocated to maximize efficiency, and about how different types of markets affect the choices of consumers and firms, among many other subjects in microeconomics. I think overall, this course helped me develop a marginal style of thinking, which I believe will be very useful in many circumstances later in life.
Broad introduction to microeconomics.

I learned so much about how economics is applied to the world as a whole--especially towards the end when we learned about insurance and monopoly (regarding patents). I feel like I learned so much beyond just mathematical concepts and have a better idea of how the world works and I'm so thankful for that.
Knowledge in important microeconomics concepts such as perfect competition/monopoly/oligopoly, etc...

I learned about economic models and concepts to explain the world as well as topics in game theory for decision making. This class taught about both positive and normative economics comparing the way things in the world actually work and how they should work based on models and assumptions.
I learned about how to think from an economical perspective in my daily life.
I learned about micro economics

Learned a lot about foundational microeconomics, new perspectives on how the world works in terms of money. I think my biggest takeaway was actually unlearning that economics wasn't a "selfish" subject  there is so much good to be done with it.
I learned how to better utilize office hours
In depth understanding of consumer and firm interactions through supply and demand in different market scenarios
I had a basic introduction to microeconomics. This class is a good introduction for anyone interested in the field.
I learned how to critically think about economic systems and how they affect people in economic markets.
Economic thinking, supply and demand, how to analyze questions part by part.
I received an introduction to economics as a discipline and as a way of thinking about the world, with an emphasis on theory as opposed to empirical reality.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Prof. Goldberg was a fine lecturer; PSets did a good job of covering the material of the week.
Weaknesses: sections seemed off-topic and a little bit of a waste of time; lectures didn't cover mathematical examples (that's all that exams and PSets were) but that's what section was for; some surprise questions on PSets and exams that felt a little unfair; grading was generally fair; peer tutors were somewhat hard to get in contact with and office hours weren't super accessible (at least for me)
I think it could have been nice to show problem application in the lectures as well.

Strengths: Student-understanding based. Unintimidating. Much P-Set help. 
Weaknesses: Long lectures which did not engage students.
This is a great class to learn about microeconomics.

The course was very accessible, and the instructors did a good job of keeping the material approachable. I found some of the review in the beginnings of lectures a bit redundant; we could have moved to new material each lecture and kept the length to an hour rather than an hour and fifteen minutes. I didn't find the content especially intellectually engaging, but then again, it's an introductory lecture. If the goal is to build a foundation for future, more interesting courses, it succeeded. I appreciated the organization of the course and the routine nature of the problem sets. I always felt prepared for exams and thought the course functioned well online. It was one of the best organized courses of my semester.

I think the strengths of this course were the number of graphs drawn to portray material, weekly sections, the review sessions hosted before each exam, and reviewing the material at the beginning of every class. A weakness would be the lack of attendance during classes.

A serious revision of this course needs to be done. There is nothing redeeming or enjoyable about this course in its current virtual state. If it weren't for my amazing TA, I simply do not know what would be okay about this course. The lectures are EXTREMELY dry and hard to follow. The most frustrating part of this class is how the review sessions and the review content you are given for the tests are never reflective of the material covered in the exams. It seems like you can never study or prep enough for what they give you. I suggest that the econ department thinks strongly about who they want to be the professors of this course & how they want to frame this course to be better for engaging students in the material & not continuing to alienate students who may not be so interested in econ.
The professors were really helpful and good at explaining concepts. There is no weaknesses to the course.

Strengths: section/office hours w section leader were the most helpful for me in learning material
Weaknesses: wish there had been more opportunities for going more in depth on more complex topics/lecture being more engaging

strengths: Canvas and assignments were well-organized; Daniela Morar was a great course director and section leader; the textbook for this class was interesting and helpful for understanding course material; the workload was manageable: weekly p sets and 2 midterms and 1 final; if you haven't taken econ in high school you might need to read the textbook more diligently which take some more time
weaknesses: little individual attention and feedback and fast paced lecture
It was hard. Go faster in beginning and slow down later.

I don't think this is Yale's strongest classthe professor clearly cared about teaching but was not the best teacher, and there is a limited willingness to hear from students. That said, this is not a super difficult course and there are a number of supports to make sure it goes well. A major strength: Joseph Ribaudo, one of the peer mentors for the course, went above and beyond to help students understand material.

I really enjoyed how Professor Goldberg recapped the previous day's lecture at the beginning of each lecture. I would have liked for there to be more questions to the class that we could be called on to answer, but I understand that that was difficult this year due to the nature of virtual learning.
The extra resources in the form of teachers assistants and peer tutors are very helpful with fully understanding course material

This class conveyed a breadth of basic information on microeconomics, and was very approachable and accessible to people like me without any background in economics at all. The workload is very manageable and standard. However, the material is dry and the second half of the course felt more rushed.

The last third of the course was taught so quickly that most students did not retain the information that was being taught. Over Zoom, and even in person, this class could benefit from a 5-minute break in the middle of the lecture because every class was packed with info. I liked that Prof Goldberg reviewed material at the start of the class. I wish that the class could have been more engaging and more interactive. Outside of the lecture, my section was not very helpful. The class could have benefitted from doing a practice problem or two during lecture.
this was a difficult class over zoom with some glitches with so many people and so many skilled economists from around the world and sometimes it was hard to understand what was said

I thought Office Hours were helpful. Joe led amazing review sessions. I thought they gave ample review material. I thought lectures were a bit slow and confusing. Also we didn't get enough time to complete exams
Great teacher and tas. Very smart and explained concepts very well

The only strength of this course was our peer tutor Joe. Without his office hours I don't think I would have completed this course which was honestly very disappointing. In lectures the professor only quickly scratched the surface of the content that we were expected to know in p-sets and exams. The lectures were very disorganized and tended to rush through major topics which made it hard to follow along with the textbook when the professor's content was insufficient. The discussion sections were a disaster. My section leader (Tolga Koker) was very hostile, unprofessional, and extremely unhelpful. As a result I stopped going to my section and instead better used the time by reviewing the content on my own. The final was extremely difficult. I have spoken with many students and we all agree that none of the lectures, sections, or review sessions prepared us for it. I also have no idea what my grade is and neither does the professor. We are given a percentage grade in canvas but she said to ignore it because she does not know what the curve will be. I truly regret taking this class this semester because I have heard such great things about the fall semester professors. This leaves me to conclude that the problem is not with the class but with the instructors.
this course was not taught well. It was hard to stay engaged. the PowerPoints were hard to follow

This class taught all the basics for an introductory microeconomics course, but I do wish it had been more interactive in terms of sections and doing practice problems. It often felt like we were given so much information and not taught what to do with that/how to apply it to problems.

Strength - effectively organized course, lots of resources, overall a good experience 
Weakness - some of the concepts could be better explained in lecture

Penny is a very clear lecturer. She is good at explaining difficult concepts and she also does a good job explaining how intro micro principles apply to real world issues like healthcare, climate change etc. 
Weaknesses- idk this is a basic intro econ class so if that doesn't interest you fundamentally then you won't enjoy this. There is definitely some learning curve if you're not a big QR person but also it's very doable to do decently well...I am definitely not a QR person!

The course is a great introduction to microeconomics with a lot of interesting commentary on the content. More discussion about the application of the material could be very nice (e.g., making some, but not all, of the optional readings necessary and covering them a little in discussion section or in lecture).

strengths: great TFs, great prof, systematic homework

weaknesses: sometimes content + teaching combined make the class a little dull
It was a really good foundational class. The challenge of big lectures though is that student engagement was low and I found it hard to find students that were passionate about learning the concepts.

Strengths: Professor Goldberg is always a win. She gives clear, compelling, amazing lectures and incorporates fascinating real-world examples to ground the often theoretical economic concepts. I found the lectures engaging and pertinent to real-world events.

Weaknesses: I found the TAs helpful but the other teaching staff to be quite cold. There was very much a "fend for yourself" attitude.

Professor Goldberg was an excellent professor: very knowledgeable and approachable
Additionally, there were an ABUNDANCE of resources to help you do well, including AMPLE office hours and peer tutor hours before every PSET, midterm or final
Taught well, although I had trouble engaging with the material

Strengths: How well it's organized and how exact it is in deadlines, grading, etc., as well as extra resources made available and really awesome section leaders.
Weaknesses: Lectures are boring and not engaging.
The virtual format and teaching style made it very unenthusiastic and somewhat hard to engage with.

There were some real weaknesses to this course. I thought that it was a tough class to focus in especially on zoom, and wasnt engaging enough for me personally. I also found the tests incomparable to the practice tests we were given, which was probably a feature of zoom/open note test taking.
The lectures based on theory were interesting however the tests were too practical and not enough practice done throughout lectures
this course was difficult to engage with, mainly because the online lecture format was something I was not used to

The course often did not relate to test material. I felt like I learned a bunch through the practice tests, problem sets, lecture, discussion sections, textbook, and review sessions. However, all of that content that I mastered outside of examinations was on the tests, yet there was often content I had never been exposed to through the variety of ways I engaged with this course. It is very confusing because I don't understand why you would test on material that had never been explored. More often than not, students with prior experience in economics benefitted from this because of this classes curve, which I think is somewhat classist.
The lectures were somewhat boring and monotone. However, it was well organized and the expectations were clear.
The lectures were not very helpful and it was more beneficial to independently read through the textbook than attend lecture; Exams are very hard; professors not accommodating

I think the strengths of the course were the great lectures by Professor Goldberg, the length of the problem sets, and the availability of office hours. The lectures were very engaging and interesting. The problem sets did not require much time, and there were office hours with peer tutors and economics professors to help you out. This was a class where you could get ample help if you sought it out. I would not necessarily call it a weakness, but I felt like the final was much harder than the midterms and problem sets.
The lectures were very dry, which made it difficult to pay attention in class. Discussion sections were very helpful in understanding the material.

Strengths: I think the peer tutors and resources provided to students to study are very helpful. There are plenty of practice problems and the psets are very helpful in gaining an understanding of the material. 
Weaknesses: Personally, the lectures were very unengaging. I found them a bit slow and difficult to get through when trying to review content. The course also picks up quite a bit after the first exam, which isn't necessarily a weakness but it is something to know.

Strengths: the teaching team is very strong and you could get help easily. The course is organized in a way that is not toooo intimidating for beginners although some of the concepts could be a little alien if youve never touched Econ before. Professor Goldberg is pretty clear with stuff.
this class was pretty informative but very boring and not very engaging at all--there could have been more interactive activities (polls) and questions and more examples of applications to real life

I wish there were options for "section" earlier in the weeks. Wednesday conflicted with my literature class. Thursday evenings were sub-optimal because I almost always had a long assignment due on Friday mornings. And the Friday options started at 5:30 or 6:00 am my time (PT). This may have just been a problem for me, but I would have preferred other options.
Awful

The lectures did not include a thorough emphasis on problem solving and applying the learned concepts on real life issues. However, the reviews in the beginnings of the lectures were helpful. Time constraint was a significant problem for every single exam administered in the course. If the exam timings are going to be the same in the future, it would be highly beneficial for the instructors to give insights and practice problem solving under a given time.

Strengths: Discussion sections were helpful in dealing with tricky concepts/problems and the math behind topics touched on in class
At the beginning of lecture, Professor Goldberg always reviewed the previous lecture's material, which was helpful at times.

Weaknesses: Both lectures and my discussion section went too fast. I often found myself having to rewatch parts of the lecture that were brushed by way too quickly.

80 minutes of straight lecturing is very exhausting. I would prefer if there was a 5 minute break in the middle of the lecture. Also, we learned a lot about specific economic terms and their mathematical models, but we never really went into depth on what they meant abstractly, or what they mean practically outside of mathematics. Im certain that 70% of the class could not accurately describe what the marginal rate of substitution means in real world terms. The strength of this course is the 15 minutes at the beginning of each class that Professor Goldberg takes to review the previous classs material. That was extremely helpful.

Strengths: Covered a lot of material in the course of one term and did a good job trying to synthesize the material at the end. Weaknesses: Lectures could be quite confusing and the professor often seemed unwilling to give much time to student's questions.

Penny is SUCH a great lecturer. I love how she usually goes over some of the concepts that we've learned in the previous lecture as a refresher, and then dives into new material. However, I feel like outside of class, I wish there was more assistance in terms of more availabilities for office hours from peer tutors.
Instructor/TFs provided very clear explanation for concepts

This course was separated into many well-defined sections which was helpful in learning in the information and the professor slides/lecture outlines were detailed and very helpful for studying. Also, all of the teachers part of the course were very helpful and accessible for questions.
The course could spend a bit less time on case studies but the material was thought clearly.
-all of it was wonderful, greatly designed
I would have liked to see more real world applications of the material

The strength of this class was the quality of the instructors. Penny Goldberg is an outstanding lecturer, and she makes the class interesting. In particular, the undergraduate learning assistant Joe was an absolutely amazing instructor. A weakness could be section turnout -- few people utilized section to the fullest.
Lots of resources outside of class for help. Well organized and structured for units to build off one another.

Strengths were that the course material was covered very in depth so it was easy to understand. A weakness was that it sometimes felt very slow at the beginning of a lecture and very rushed by the end.
A strength is the amount of practice we got as well as how we reviewed the material from past classes as the course progressed. A weakness is the lack of engagement opportunities during lectures.

The lectures were very theoretical. Which is understandable. However, I would prefer more practice questions in the lectures as well. It the examples were side by side with the theory, I am sure I would gain a better understanding of the work and I would perform better in the tests.

The course is well structured so that new material is introduced at a pace that keeps things interesting without it being overwhelming. The sections with the TFs are useful for getting additional practice on concepts you feel shaky on, but they don't provide any additional knowledge or insights if you are understanding the course material.

I found the general atmosphere of the course to be stressful and my section leader, while helpful, was extremely negative, telling us to prepare to fail our exams because they would have to make the exams much harder this semester due to their online format. This was not encouraging. I found the lectures to be hard to follow because they were long and there were days when I wasnt sure the professors heart was really in it. The professors presentation was always somewhat monotonous. I found the final exam to not be very representative of the review sessions (all of which I attended) and felt frustrated by the exam after I had worked so hard all semester and done well (had an A). I also found it difficult to take this class virtually because they were not accommodating of West Coast students (we had to push for the final exam time to be moved to a better time for us).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think being able to watch lectures on your own time was helpful, but following a discussion leader's work on a whiteboard would definitely be easier in person.
Discussion sections worked well. The lecture format was more difficult (I did not feel engaged or like I was learning from the lectures).
Everything was great and the level of engagement was high.

Having recorded lectures and uploaded lecture slides was very helpful for later reviewI would try to keep recording and uploading even after the pandemic. I think section would have been much better in person. The groups were just the wrong size where it felt intimidating to speak up but also too small to not participate. Stated expectations at the onset of the course about whether or not cameras should be on or off also would have been helpful. I thought the office hours with the peer tutors, even over Zoom, were especially helpful.
I think that recording all the lectures and review sessions were an added bonus during covid. However, this did lead to big drops in attendance.
The recorded zoom lectures were really helpful for someone who is enrolled online
Nothing improved

This course being recorded was probably a good thing during the pandemic. Through Zoom, the whole format of a whiteboard lecture simply isn't that engaging as the lecturer is on a different part of the screen than the learning material.
I really enjoyed having the small discussion sections. Additionally, office hours over Zoom made connecting with my TA very accessible.
It was perfect

Very idiotic decision by the Econ classes to refuse to offer the other Introductory Micro courses this year (specifically 108 and 110).   This decision reflected a lack of commitment to maintaining the level of teaching during the pandemic and I found the decision to no longer offer a more analytical (math-based) econ class for those students who are in advanced math levels to be offensive and honestly lazy.

There should have been a 5-minute break in the middle of lecture. The class material was overwhelming, especially since the professor often went overtime. I don't think the course really accommodated for virtual learning at all besides the lectures being recorded. That was helpful. I am thankful for the peer tutors because I wouldn't have survived this course without their help.
Lectures were very good.
the sections were very helpful as it showed practice problems and how to do them, though that was it.
Lecture recording posted timely, effective resources

i thought covid practices were fine, really appreciated the recorded review sessions for midterms and finals.
HOWEVER, i really did not appreciate that the econ department did not respect the break days set out by Yale College and continued to assign psets/hold sections directly after; it really went against the spirit of break days.

The course was very flexible with the recorded lecture format and worked very well. I would hope in the future that such heavy lecture courses with large enrollment would continue to offer an asynchronous option, especially since they are often scheduled right in the middle of the day. I took this course asynchronously.
The fact that classes were recorded made it really easy for students to slack off/avoid attending/watching lectures.

I believe the virtual lectures and discussion sections worked well. I wish there was more attempt to engage on the side of the teaching staff, but I understand that COVID complicated the situation. I also wish that feedback was given directly on our exam rather than just receiving a raw score with no explanation other than an answer key to compare my answers to.
Office hours and answers posted on sets, and lectures posted regularly
The lectures lacked engagement and charisma partially due to the online format

The peer tutor office hours worked well (shout out to joe) but lectures were super long and pretty boring at times. I struggled to get through them as did many others. Most people seemed to just stop going entirely, choosing instead to watch it asynchronously.

Lectures were often very boring and not engaging due to limited opportunity for class participation. This was not necessarily bad, but I feel most of my learning occurred outside of class during review sessions and discussion sections. I know lectures aren't supposed to be that active, but Zoom is a different environment, so occasional polls or class participation would've been nice.
Discussion section allowed for engagement but I did not attend them.
The review sessions were helpful, especially those that were recorded and uploaded; Exam procedure was unfair

I think the live lectures were done very well. They covered all of the material necessary for the exams and assignments. Professor Goldberg was very engaging and worked hard to make the lectures easy to follow. I particularly enjoyed the review of last time at the beginning of each lecture. It was nice that there were no pre-lecture videos or required readings for the course. Discussion sections were a great opportunity to talk to kids in class and learn in a much smaller group with an economics professor. It made lecture feel all the more important. I do not think any improvements could be made in this regard.

The Zoom lectures were particularly difficult to sit through; I did not find them very engaging and the material was somewhat redundant. The discussion sections were mainly classroom style practice problems, which I did find helpful.
I guess more people could have come to section but somehow our section ended up being just 3 people each week

it was basically just like watching boring khan academy videos--there wasn't much virtual engagement at all as the professor seemed to give up half way through the course at any sort of class participation

Dr. Goldberg did a great job as a lecturer; I watched all of her lectures, and took notes on all of her lectures. However, I could never make much sense of the lecture from the lecture notes (powerpoint). For those who want to fill in the gaps of their knowledge and revisit a lecture (but without more video screen time!), better accompanying lecture/content notes would be greatly appreciated.
Make learning in person

Recording lectures was beneficial for me, as it allowed me to revisit topics I was unclear about or watch any lecture I had missed. I think discussion sections could have been made a little bit longer, just so they wouldn't be as rushed and students could have more time to ask questions. I think more of an emphasis should have been placed on being able to ask questions out loud in lecture, rather than just having students type questions in the chat, as many of the answers given were unclear / didn't give any further explanation to a tricky concept.

The lectures were recorded which helped to accommodate students that weren't on the east coast--there were many accommodations throughout the semester for midterms and tests for those in different parts of the world. The lectures were top-notch! There was not super engagement, but that's expected from a lecture-type of class.
The virtual office hours were very helpful and TFs offered the students a lot of different opportunities to attend office hours
The combination of virtual lectures and discussion sections, with more independent learning, were successful in overcoming challenges with COVID-19.
The course could have a more interactive aspect, but the section material and recorded review sessions were helpful
It was well adapted for online learning
I feel like the course needed more synchronous components.
The engagement during the lecture was low -- few people asked questions.
I think all the practices succeeded. The discussion sections were very good as my leader used a whiteboard like in a normal classroom.

A success was the plentiful office hour opportunities and the amount of practice we had access to before tests. Recorded lectures were put up very fast as well. There were no weaknesses related to the pandemic.
I was not engaged in the lectures. I found it very hard to follow the teacher compared to other classes I had.

The live Zoom lectures allow for students to ask questions, but I found myself almost always watching the recorded version later because I enjoyed being able to watch them at my leisure and stop or rewind the lecture when I didn't understand something.
Asynchronous lectures

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're interested in economics, yes. You learn a great deal, but be prepared to do a lot of it on your own. Lectures often lay a conceptual foundation and sections present the basic mathematical concepts, but many of the PSet and exam problems are more complex than what was previously presented in the class.
I would recommend this course to a student confident in their quantitive abilities, yet willing to maintain interest when the content becomes a bit dry.
Yes, this is an important course for learning microeconomics and can be applied to many areas.
everyone should learn at least a little and this class is a great place to start

I would recommend this course to another student who hopes to build a basic literacy with economic terms and modes of thought. As someone who will spend money and pay taxes for the rest of their lives, the skills you build in introductory micro will prepare you to save, invest, and vote. It is a good foundation for future classes, and I always felt that the expectations for students were clear and manageable. If you're trying to balance a heavier semester, I also think this course functions well as a fifth credit.

I would totally recommend this course to any student, even if they are not necessarily mathematically advanced. You learn many interesting topics that can used and applied to the real world at a level of algebra that I believe anyone can handle.

Please only take this course if you think you are majoring in economics or need it for a pre-req. Do not waste your time taking this course if you need a QR--there are plenty of other more enjoyable QR credits out there.
I would recommend this course to others even if they aren't thinking of majoring in econ becaus the course is very applicable to everyday life.

Probably, it's intro micro so if you're looking to jump into Econ without having taken other Econ before than it's a good place to start - the lecture format can be disengaging at times but I think that is improved when it's in person and you can find people to do p-sets/study with
Yes. The course itself isn't too exciting but it's a useful prerequisite for Macro, Econometrics, and many interesting electives.
Yes! a basic understanding of microeconomics is helpful no matter what your major is.
Yea, its necessary for a lot.
I don't think there's any way around this course, honestly, and I think it's worth taking if you have not taken any microeconomics before.
Yes! It provides an excellent foundation for learning about the economy.
Yes, this course really lets you understand the thoughts behind your everyday decisions.
no

If you are interested in exploring economics and since this course is a prereq for many majors, then yes. As a humanities major, this course was fine and not challenging, so I would recommend it to anyone.
If you want to learn about economics, yes. If you take the class, prepare to do a lot of learning on your own. The lectures are not very helpful at all
Yes, it's a good way to get a feel of economics and if you like it.
Yes. Very good and insightful
Not with these professors.
Yes as it is a prerequisite and a lot of people do it, so it's something to have in common. The concepts are really cool, thought overall it is not taught that well.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless you need to take this class as a prerequisite for a later course.
I would recommend this if you think you want to do something with economics in the future. Otherwise, it did not really pique my interest in economics more than my existing interest.
Yes, if you have not done any economics or if you want to refresh your memory.
I would recommend this course to those students who want to gain a foundational understanding of economics concepts.

Sure, especially if you need a QR or need it as foundational learning for classes you're interested in; econ is a very helpful thing to have a general surface knowledge of because people reference it so much, it's very satisfying for things to finally click! However, keep in mind it by far won't be the most unique or scintillating class in your schedule
I would recommend it to anyone who needs it or who is looking for a basic economics foundation. There are some skills covered that will be applicable to general living, not just economics study.
yes, if you're interested in an intro-level class to economics.
YES - a really important class for all students independent of their major. It really helped me have a better understanding of economics in its relation to politics, policy, and human behavior.

I am not an econ major, but took this course to gain a better understanding of economics and to fulfill a social sciences credit. I would recommend this to anyone with a solid background in math and logic concepts. There is a lot of problem-solving in the form of word problems. For those not majoring in econ or who don't have an interest, this course is probably more trouble than it's worth.
Yes so that you can see if economics is something you'd enjoy
In my opinion, any educated person should take introductory microeconomics, especially at Yale.

Not really, unless you need to take it or are particularly interested in economics. It's pretty boring material otherwise, and particularly frustrating if you know much math because the math parts are dumbed down somewhat.
Try to take this one with a good professor if you can. Goldberg was boring. But I think everyone should take economics, it is so important to the world as a whole.
Yes if you want to take econ, no otherwise.

No, dont take it, especially if you dont have any economics background. Hands down the worst course Ive taken thus far at Yale (reminder that this was the online version). I wish I had listened to everyone who told me not to take it. It takes up so much time and energy that can be devoted elsewhere and caused a lot of stress.
Yes in order to gain a better understanding of how to think like an economist
I would not recommend this course of the same professor was teaching.
Only as a major requirement.

I wouldn't recommend this course unless a student needs it as a prerequisite for a particular major. I feel like I learned some things, but I also feel like I didn't get nearly as much as I should have out of this class.
Yes, as it is a req for a lot of other related coursework, especially in political science / ep&e
Yes, it is a solid intro econ class.
Only if its required

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Whether you want to be an economics major or not, this course is very interesting and makes you think about actions taken by companies and governments much differently. You gain a basic understanding of microeconomics, and the course is not particularly hard. I felt that the problem sets were fair and manageable every week. Discussion section is a great way to clear up concerns in the class, and Professors Koker and Morar were great. The midterms were very fair and not too difficult as long as you studied a good amount. However, the final was pretty difficult compared to the other work in the course. However, grades are curved and the course overall is fantastic.

I am pre-med and have never taken an economics course before, so I wanted to try this class out to see if I would like it. I didn't end up enjoying it much, but if you have any interest in learning economics, it's probably worth trying out.

I would recommend this course if you know you have a vested interest in economics/want to pursue something econ related. I personally do not and didn't find much value in taking the course outside of learning some basic economic principles. It wasn't that interesting to me because of it.
It's a fine prereq to take. Some parts are interesting, and it's useful to know in general. You won't love the class unless you're already interested in econ I think.
Yes, essential
Maybe if you want some exposure to Econ and a QR credit. The math is not super hard but you have to be able to understand the concepts

Yeah, I mean it's required so I guess you just gotta get it out of the way. if you like it, you'll probably like econ. i didn't have much of an econ background so i thought this course owuld be interesting and while i did learn a decent amount it did not pique my interest at all though if it was taught differently it might have
Sure! I had a fine experience. But it is also a pre-requisite for many things (and a huge lecture course), so it's not the type of course I'd go out of my way to recommend as a fourth course.
Never
Only if you are planning to take other advanced economics classes.

Yes, particularly if this is your first course in economics. Honestly, I think the most valuable takeaway from this course is the marginal style of thinking so many economics courses preach. Besides this, most of the course isn't very practical and will really just help you prepare for further courses in the econ department.
If theyre interested in casually learning about economics, no. Youre better off taking the small, introductory seminars that the ECON major offers than a large lecture course like this.
I would recommend it if you need it for your major or are considering majoring in economics, but otherwise no.

Yes, even if you're not planning on majoring in economics, this class gives you so much perspective on the world. Penny tries her best to not place emphasis on the mathematics, but more on the concepts, and she is SUCH a great lecturer. She explains things very clearly, and you just learn so much about how economics is applied to the world as a whole--especially towards the end when we learned about insurance and monopoly (regarding patents). I now have a better idea of how the world works and I'm so thankful for that. 

Given the circumstances of COVID, we had additional support from other professors, however, I would've liked more support on the problem sets if there were more availabilities from other professors or peer tutors. There are however multiple study sessions throughout the semester--take advantage of these and go to office hours!
Yes, I thought the content and professor were both enjoyable. Good support system if you want it, but you can do pretty well on your own without the help.
Yes, if you are interested in economics. It also provides insights into how economics and society/political policies intersect
I would recommend this course to another student because the information was not too difficult to grasp and the economic concepts were very interesting to learn about.
Yes, this course is a good overview of economics
Yes
If you need to take it for a requirement, it has interesting concepts so it wont be too bad. If you want to take it just to fulfill a QR requirement, dont. It is really hard and the work is boring.
Yes

Yes, but Id caution anyone taking to course for its general appeal instead of as a pre-req. While there course definitely did have worthwhile general value, there might be other courses that have the same appeal that do a better job of generating student engagement (though this might be a covid-only problem).
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants a good introduction to microeconomics, and haven't taken AP microeconomics.
Yes, especially for an Econ major it was a great starting point.
Id recommend this course to anybody because its very easy to follow and teaches a lot of interesting economic models.
Yep! Super good introductory course with a lot of opportunities to practice, including very helpful discussion sections.
Yes, as I believe it is a good introductory course to Economics. However, I would not recommend taking this course remotely.

I would recommend this course to any student at Yale college. Economics is not just about the economy but is also a way of analyzing decision making which is applicable to any individual's daily life, even if they are not planning on going into a field involving economics,
Only if they need a QR credit/are interested in the Econ major.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Discussion section once a week
Lectures were recorded and a weekly discussion section was also used.
There were also discussion sessions weekly.
Live virtual lecture with one weekly 50-minute discussion section.
Live virtual lecture, recorded lecture, virtual discussion sections.
discussion sections
I usually attended Zoom lectures live, which were then recorded and posted online. We also had synchronous sections once a week taught by professors.
Live lecture, discussion sections
virtual lecture
Weekly discussion sections.
weekly virtual discussion sections
with live section
Lectures were recorded; there was a non-mandatory discussion section component to this class.
We had a live, virtual lecture that we could also watch recorded if need be twice per week. In addition to the lecture, we had small discussion sections once per week.
Recorded lecture + Weekly Discussion Section
The class was taught live virtually, but it was recorded. I took another course that overlapped with ECON 115, so I ended up watching the Wednesday lectures asynchronously.
also recorded
None
Twice weekly recorded lecture and an optional weekly small group discussion section.
Recorded lecture with an asynchronous discussion section.
section
There were live virtual lectures twice a week which were recorded, and a discussion section every week as well.
Live sections
Also virtual seminar
live virtual lecture + virtual discussion section
The lectures were recorded so they could be watched at a later time.
Live virtual lecture and virtual seminar
section once a week in a smaller group
virtual discussion
Recorded lecture and virtual discussion section
live virtual lecture, virtual seminar
Sections as well.
review sessions and discussion sections.
Watched both live and virtual lectures
Sometimes went to live lectures. Never went to discussion section
None
The course was structured with two live/recorded lectures and a discussion section every week.
Lectures were recorded and we had non-mandatory section.
In-person section
Recorded live lecture
Virtual discussion sections
recorded lecture
Office Hours with a TA, peer review sessions with Joe
A combination of recorded and live virtual lecture
Live virtual lecture that was recorded for asynchronous viewing.
Lecture offered live and also recorded, along with weekly discussion sections.
All of the lectures were synchronous, however, also recorded, which allowed students to take the class asynchronously as well.
Office hours
I took the course asynchronously.
Live virtual lecture + sections
This class was a combination of live virtual lectures and weekly virtual discussion sections.
Lectures were recorded and could be watched asynchronously
-section
Everything was recorded also
The lectures were live, but I only attended the first lecture live; the rest I watched recorded.
Live virtual lecture and virtual discussion.
Office hours and review sessions.
Recorded
Recorded lecture and discussion section once a week.
Section with TF over Zoom
Virtual Discussion Session
Recorded Lectures, Synchronous Sections
